From: Vassilis Vassiliades <vassilisvas@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve modular
 artificial neural networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=434634266; y=1ar-ZoqTbRPPz2YjFtmUFdUHZK6ZpB5N-6nKh9Jsg7AzXP0vYp8g1Q

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello Jeff,

First, I'd also like to congratulate you and your co-authors o=
n this
interesting paper.

My question is about the second objective, which=
 I initially thought it was
a connection cost, but as I read in Section 4(j=
):

"The second objective prioritizes individuals that are far away from ot=
her
individuals already discovered by the algorithm, where distance is meas=
ured
in a Cartesian space with connection costs on the x-axis and modularit=
y on
the y-axis".

So, if I understand correctly, the second objective is n=
ot simply a
connection cost, but you also take the modularity metric into a=
ccount and
explore in a novelty search kind of way.

Is this correct? How d=
o you believe the algorithm would perform if the
second objective was simpl=
y either a connection cost or the modularity
metric, or perhaps have both a=
s separate objectives (3-objective problem)?


Best,

Vassilis


On Wed, Fe=
b 6, 2013 at 7:57 PM, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
> Hell=
o all,
>
> I'm extremely pleased to announce a new paper on a subject that
=
> many--including myself--think is critical to making significant progress =
in
> our field: the evolution of modularity.
>
> Jean-Baptiste Mouret, Hod =
Lipson and I have a new paper that
>
> 1) sheds light on why modularity may=
 evolve in biological networks (e.g.
> neural, genetic, metabolic, protein-=
protein, etc.)
>
> 2) provides a simple technique for evolving neural netwo=
rks that are
> modular and have increased evolvability, in that they adapt =
faster to new
> environments. The modules that formed solved subproblems in=
 the domain.
>
> Cite: Clune J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) The evolutionar=
y origins of
> modularity. Proceedings of the Royal Society B. 280: 2012286=
3.
> http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2012.2863 (pdf<http://jeffclune.com/pub=
lications/2013-CluneEtAl-EvolutionaryOriginsModularity-RoyalSociety.pdf>
> =
)
>
> Abstract: A central biological question is how natural organisms are =
so
> evolvable (capable of quickly adapting to new environments). A key dri=
ver
> of evolvability is the widespread modularity of biological networks=
=E2=80=94their
> organization as functional, sparsely connected subunits=E2=
=80=94but there is no
> consensus regarding why modularity itself evolved. =
Although most hypotheses
> assume indirect selection for evolvability, here=
 we demonstrate that the
> ubiquitous, direct selection pressure to reduce =
the cost of connections
> between network nodes causes the emergence of mod=
ular networks.
> Computational evolution experiments with selection pressur=
es to maximize
> network performance and minimize connection costs yield ne=
tworks that are
> significantly more modular and more evolvable than contro=
l experiments that
> only select for performance. These results will cataly=
se research in
> numerous disciplines, such as neuroscience and genetics, a=
nd enhance our
> ability to harness evolution for engineering purposes.
>
>=
 Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_aW8L=
Mng
>
> There has been some nice coverage of this work in the popular press=
, in
> case you are interested:
>
> National Geographic:
> http://phenomena=
.nationalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/
> MIT's Technology Re=
view:
> http://www.technologyreview.com/view/428504/computer-scientists-rep=
roduce-the-evolution-of-evolvability/
>
> Fast Company:
> http://www.fastco=
mpany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-robots-creep-closer-animal-learning
> Corn=
ell Chronicle:
> http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan13/modNetwork.html
=
> ScienceDaily:
> http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130130082300=
.htm
>
> Please let me know what you think and if you have any questions. I=
 hope
> this work will help our field move forward!
>
>
>
> Best regards,
>=
 *Jeff Clune*
>
> Assistant Professor
> Computer Science
> University of Wy=
oming
> jclune@...
> jeffclune.com
>
>

<div dir=3D"ltr"><div>Hello Jeff,</div><div><br></div><div>First, I'd a=
lso like to congratulate you and your co-authors on this interesting paper.=
</div><div><br></div><div>My question is about the second objective, which =
I initially thought it was a connection cost, but as I read in Section 4(j)=
:</div>
<div><br></div><div>"The second objective prioritizes individu=
als that are far away from other individuals already discovered by the algo=
rithm, where distance is measured in a Cartesian space with connection cost=
s on the x-axis and modularity on the y-axis".</div>
<div><br></div><d=
iv>So, if I understand correctly, the second objective is not simply a conn=
ection cost, but you also take the modularity metric into account and explo=
re in a novelty search kind of way.</div><div><br></div>
<div>Is this corre=
ct? How do you believe the algorithm would perform if the second objective =
was simply either a connection cost or the modularity metric, or perhaps ha=
ve both as separate objectives (3-objective problem)?</div>
<div><br></div>=
<div><br></div><div>Best,</div><div><br></div><div>Vassilis</div><div class=
=3D"gmail_extra"><br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Wed, Feb 6, 2013 at =
7:57 PM, Jeff Clune <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:jclune@...=
m" target=3D"_blank">jclune@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>
<blockquote=
 class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc soli=
d;padding-left:1ex">


<u></u>










<div style>
<span>=C2=A0</span>


=
<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p></p><div><div><div><span s=
tyle=3D"border-collapse:separate"><div>Hello all,</div><div><br></div><div>=
I'm extremely pleased to announce a new paper on a subject that many--i=
ncluding myself--think is critical to making significant progress in our fi=
eld: the evolution of modularity.=C2=A0</div>
<div><br></div><div>Jean-Bapt=
iste Mouret, Hod Lipson and I have a new paper that=C2=A0</div><div><br></d=
iv><div>1) sheds light on why modularity may evolve in biological networks =
(e.g. neural, genetic, metabolic, protein-protein, etc.)</div>
<div><br></d=
iv><div>2) provides a simple technique for evolving neural networks that ar=
e modular and have increased evolvability, in that they adapt faster to new=
 environments. The modules that formed solved subproblems in the domain.=C2=
=A0</div>
<div><br></div>Cite:=C2=A0Clune J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) Th=
e evolutionary origins of modularity. Proceedings of the Royal Society B. 2=
80: 20122863.=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2012.2863" tar=
get=3D"_blank"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0,102,204)">http://dx.doi.org/10.10=
98/rspb.2012.2863</span></a>=C2=A0(<a href=3D"http://jeffclune.com/publicat=
ions/2013-CluneEtAl-EvolutionaryOriginsModularity-RoyalSociety.pdf" target=
=3D"_blank"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0,102,204)">pdf</span></a>)<div style=
=3D"color:rgb(24,24,24)">
<br></div><div style=3D"color:rgb(24,24,24)">Abst=
ract: A central biological question is how natural organisms are so evolvab=
le (capable of quickly adapting to new environments). A key driver of evolv=
ability is the widespread modularity of biological networks=E2=80=94their o=
rganization as functional, sparsely connected subunits=E2=80=94but there is=
 no consensus regarding why modularity itself evolved. Although most hypoth=
eses assume indirect selection for evolvability, here we demonstrate that t=
he ubiquitous, direct selection pressure to reduce the cost of connections =
between network nodes causes the emergence of modular networks. Computation=
al evolution experiments with selection pressures to maximize network perfo=
rmance and minimize connection costs yield networks that are significantly =
more modular and more evolvable than control experiments that only select f=
or performance. These results will catalyse research in numerous discipline=
s, such as neuroscience and genetics, and enhance our ability to harness ev=
olution for engineering purposes.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Video:=C2=A0<a =
href=3D"http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_=
aW8LMng" target=3D"_blank">http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=3Dplayer_em=
bedded&v=3DSG4_aW8LMng</a></div><div><br></div><div>
There has been som=
e nice coverage of this work in the popular press, in case you are interest=
ed:</div><div><br></div><li style=3D"color:rgb(71,135,255)"><span style=3D"=
color:rgb(0,0,0)">National Geographic:=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://phenomena.nat=
ionalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/" target=3D"_blank">http:/=
/phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/</a></span><=
/li>
<li><font color=3D"#040404">MIT's Technology Review:</font><span s=
tyle=3D"color:rgb(71,135,255)">=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://www.technologyreview=
.com/view/428504/computer-scientists-reproduce-the-evolution-of-evolvabilit=
y/" target=3D"_blank">http://www.technologyreview.com/view/428504/computer-=
scientists-reproduce-the-evolution-of-evolvability/</a>=C2=A0</span></li>
<=
li style=3D"color:rgb(71,135,255)"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0,0,0)">Fast Co=
mpany:=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://www.fastcompany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-ro=
bots-creep-closer-animal-learning" target=3D"_blank">http://www.fastcompany=
.com/3005313/evolved-brains-robots-creep-closer-animal-learning</a></span><=
/li>
<li style=3D"color:rgb(71,135,255)"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0,0,0)">C=
ornell Chronicle:=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan13=
/modNetwork.html" target=3D"_blank">http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan=
13/modNetwork.html</a></span></li>
<li style=3D"color:rgb(71,135,255)"><spa=
n style=3D"color:rgb(0,0,0)">ScienceDaily:=C2=A0<a href=3D"http://www.scien=
cedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130130082300.htm" target=3D"_blank">http://www=
.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130130082300.htm</a></span></li>
<div><b=
r></div><div>Please let me know what you think and if you have any question=
s. I hope this work will help our field move forward!</div><div><br></div><=
/span></div></div></div><div><div><span style=3D"border-collapse:separate">=
<div>
